newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Caltex sees lower crude price for rest of the year.
newsitem.headline: Caltex sees lower crude price for rest of the year.

text.p: Crude oil prices are expected to come under downward pressure for the rest of the year, reversing recent rises, as the market has largely discounted the absence of Iraqi oil, the head of Caltex Petroleum Corp said on Monday.
"The market seemed to have discounted Iraqi oil this year," Caltex chairman David J. Law-Smith told Reuters in an interview.
"It is largely dependent on what happened to the weather and what happened to demand, which is very high in the last two months of the year."
"Our view is that there is downward pressure and not upward pressure."
He said most refineries calculated the price of Dubai crude to be around the $16-to-$18 per barrel level.
Dubai soared to $21.62 a barrel during the peak of the Gulf crisis in the first week of September, when the United States launched missiles against Iraqi air defense targets.
"Caltex Petroleum's view is that (Dubai) prices will come down to the $18 level," he said.
Some oil analysts said they expected crude prices to remain high due to the continued absence of Iraqi oil which had been widely expected to return to world markets this month.

After Baghdad's military incursion into northern Kurdish areas, which prompted the U.S. strikes, the United Nations delayed indefinitely an oil-for-food plan allowing Iraq to sell oil worth $2.0 billion over six months to buy humanitarian supplies.
